questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the office with a 6-week history of pain in his right wrist. He is a professional drummer, and the pain developed during a tour with his band. The pain is temporarily relieved with ibuprofen and wrist immobilization. He has no history of recent trauma or injury to the wrist. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals approximately 70° of extension in the left and right wrists, 65° of flexion in the right wrist, and 80° of flexion in the left wrist. His carrying angle is approximately 5° bilaterally. Further examination is most likely to reveal which of the following findings in the right upper extremity?

choices.text: Restricted lateral glide of olecranon
Restricted medial glide of carpal bones
Restricted anterior glide of carpal bones
Restricted posterior glide of carpal bones
Restricted lateral glide of carpal bones
Restricted medial glide of olecranon

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Restricted lateral glide of the olecranon occurs in abduction of the ulna. Abduction of the ulna manifests with restricted abduction of the wrist, restricted medial glide of the distal ulna, and an increased carrying angle (> 15°), none of which is seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Carpal bone somatic dysfunctions manifest with restricted posterior or anterior glide, not with restricted medial glide.

C) INCORRECT:

Restricted anterior glide of the proximal carpal bones (i.e., the lunate, scaphoid, and triquetral), which articulate with the distal radius, is characteristic of wrist flexion somatic dysfunctions rather than wrist extension somatic dysfunctions.

D) CORRECT:

In wrist extension dysfunctions, the proximal carpal bones (i.e., the lunate, scaphoid, and triquetral), which articulate with the distal radius, move freely in anterior glide but are restricted in posterior glide.

E) INCORRECT:

Carpal bone somatic dysfunctions manifest with restricted posterior or anterior glide, not with restricted lateral glide.

F) INCORRECT:

Restricted medial glide of the olecranon occurs in adduction of the ulna. Adduction of the ulna manifests with restricted adduction of the wrist, restricted lateral glide of the distal ulna, and a decreased carrying angle (< 3°), none of which is seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's right wrist has full range of motion in extension and is restricted in flexion, which indicates a right-sided wrist extension somatic dysfunction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a one-day history of pain in the left forearm. She reports that the pain began after spending several hours typing at work. She denies any history of trauma or previous similar episodes. Her medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals a medial deviation of the olecranon and adduction of the wrist on the left side. There is tenderness on palpation around the proximal forearm, but no swelling or erythema. Range of motion of the elbow is full. Which of the following somatic dysfunctions is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Interosseous membrane dysfunction
Abduction of the ulna
Posterior radial head
Anterior radial head
Adduction of the ulna

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interosseous membrane dysfunction causes pain along the membrane and may result in altered pronation and supination, neither of which are seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Abduction of the ulna causes an increased carrying angle that is > 15° (cubitus valgus), lateral deviation of the forearm at the elbow (i.e., medial deviation of the olecranon and lateral deviation of the distal ulna), and adduction of the wrist.

C) INCORRECT:

Posterior radial head dysfunction is commonly due to a fall onto an outstretched pronated hand and causes restricted supination of the forearm and restricted anterior glide of the radial head, neither of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior radial head dysfunction is commonly due to a backward fall onto a supinated hand and causes restricted pronation of the forearm and restricted posterior glide of the radial head, neither of which are seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Adduction of the ulna causes a decreased carrying angle that is < 3° (cubitus varus), medial deviation of the forearm at the elbow (i.e., lateral deviation of the olecranon and medial deviation of the distal ulna), and abduction of the wrist. This patient presents with a medial deviation of the olecranon and adduction of the wrist, making another somatic dysfunction more likely.
questions.hint: Medial deviation of the olecranon and adduction of the wrist indicate an increased carrying angle of the left forearm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-day history of right forearm pain. The symptoms began after she tripped and landed on her outstretched right hand. Ibuprofen provides some pain relief. Past medical history is unremarkable. She is very active and exercises regularly. Examination of the right elbow reveals a normal carrying angle but range of motion is limited in supination. Radiography of the right hand and elbow is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Abduction somatic dysfunction of the ulna
Medial epicondylitis
Posterior radial head dysfunction
Adduction somatic dysfunction of the ulna
Interosseous membrane dysfunction
Anterior radial head dysfunction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abduction dysfunctions of the ulna cause an increased carrying angle, adduction of the wrist, and restricted medial glide of the distal ulna. Abduction of the ulna does not cause restricted supination of the forearm. In addition, this patient's carrying angle is normal rather than increased.

B) INCORRECT:

Medial epicondylitis, or golfer's elbow, is a strain of the flexor muscles of the forearm at the medial epicondyle and is typically caused by activities involving repetitive wrist flexion. Patients experience pain over the medial epicondyle that worsens with wrist flexion and pronation against resistance. Medial epicondylitis does not typically cause restricted supination of the forearm.

C) CORRECT:

Posterior radial head dysfunction is commonly caused by a fall onto an outstretched pronated hand. Pronation of the forearm causes the radial head to glide posteriorly, and a forceful impact pushes the distal radius anterior and the radial head even further posterior. This results in restricted supination of the forearm and restricted anterior glide of the radial head.

D) INCORRECT:

Adduction dysfunctions of the ulna cause a decreased carrying angle, abduction of the wrist, and restricted lateral glide of the distal ulna. Adduction of the ulna does not cause restricted supination of the forearm. In addition, this patient's carrying angle is normal rather than decreased.

E) INCORRECT:

Direct trauma to the interosseous membrane can result in persistent elbow or wrist dysfunctions even after proper management. However, this patient's fall onto her outstretched pronated hand and subsequent forearm pain and restricted supination make a different diagnosis more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Anterior radial head dysfunction is commonly caused by a backward fall onto a supinated hand. Supination of the forearm causes the radial head to glide anteriorly, and a forceful impact pushes the distal radius posterior and the proximal radial head even further anterior. This results in restricted pronation of the forearm and restricted posterior glide of the radial head.
questions.hint: On further examination, anterior glide of the radial head is restricted.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-day history of right forearm pain. The symptoms began after she tripped and landed on her outstretched right hand. Ibuprofen provides some pain relief. Past medical history is unremarkable. She is very active and exercises regularly. Examination of the right elbow reveals a normal carrying angle but range of motion is limited in supination. Radiography of the right hand and elbow is normal. A diagnosis of posterior radial head dysfunction is made and the patient consents to high velocity, low amplitude (HVLA) manipulation. HVLA manipulation for this dysfunction involves positioning the patient's forearm in

choices.text: extension while applying an anteriorly directed thrust to the radial head
abduction while applying an anteriorly directed thrust to the radial head
flexion while applying an anteriorly directed thrust to the radial head
flexion while applying a posteriorly directed thrust to the radial head
extension while applying a posteriorly directed thrust to the radial head

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

To engage the restrictive barrier of the radial head in a posterior radial head dysfunction, the forearm needs to be in extension and supination. To perform HVLA, the thumb is placed over the posterior aspect of the radial head and an anteriorly directed thrust is applied to facilitate anterior movement of the radial head past the restrictive barrier.

B) INCORRECT:

An anterior thrust is appropriate for treating a posterior radial head dysfunction. However, abduction of the forearm does not engage the restrictive barrier, which is necessary to perform HVLA.

C) INCORRECT:

An anteriorly directed thrust is appropriate for treating a posterior radial head dysfunction. However, flexion of the forearm moves the radial head posteriorly in the direction of ease rather than toward the restrictive barrier.

D) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the forearm moves the radial head posterior, which does not engage the restrictive barrier in a posterior radial head dysfunction. Furthermore, a posteriorly directed thrust would move the radial head in the direction of ease rather than toward the restrictive barrier.

E) INCORRECT:

Extension is the correct forearm position to perform HVLA on a posterior radial head dysfunction. However, a posteriorly directed thrust would move the radial head in the direction of ease rather than toward the restrictive barrier.
questions.hint: To perform HVLA, the physician needs to engage the restrictive barrier of the radial head.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the office with a 5-day history of right elbow pain after a fall while rollerblading. He has difficulty rotating his right forearm, especially when turning door handles. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lateral aspect of the right elbow, restricted pronation, and restricted posterior glide of the radial head. An x-ray of the elbow reveals no fractures. To treat this patient's condition with muscle energy, he should be instructed to

choices.text: radially deviate the right wrist against counterforce
extend the right elbow against counterforce
flex the right elbow against counterforce
pronate the right forearm against counterforce
supinate the right forearm against counterforce

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radial deviation of the wrist primarily affects the wrist joint and does not directly influence the position or movement of the radial head. This patient has an anterior radial head dysfunction with a pronation barrier, which requires contracting the forearm muscles in the direction of ease during muscle energy treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Extension of the right elbow against counterforce is used to treat restricted elbow flexion, which can be caused by triceps muscle spasm. This patient has an anterior radial head dysfunction with a pronation barrier, which requires contracting the forearm muscles in the direction of ease during muscle energy treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the right elbow against counterforce is used to treat restricted elbow extension, which can be caused by biceps muscle spasm. This patient has an anterior radial head dysfunction with a pronation barrier, which requires contracting the forearm muscles in the direction of ease during muscle energy treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Pronation of the right forearm against counterforce is appropriate for muscle energy treatment of a posterior radial head dysfunction, which manifests with restricted anterior glide of the radial head and restricted supination. This patient has an anterior radial head dysfunction with a pronation barrier, which requires contracting the forearm muscles in the direction of ease during muscle energy treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Supination of the right forearm moves the radial head anteriorly, which is the direction of ease in an anterior radial head dysfunction. To treat this condition with muscle energy, the patient's forearm is first placed into pronation, which causes the radial head to glide posteriorly to engage the restrictive barrier. Then, the patient is instructed to supinate his forearm against an equal counterforce applied by the physician for 3–5 seconds, causing reflexive relaxation of the supinator muscle group. After a short period of relaxation, the procedure is repeated, and the dysfunction is reassessed. Relaxation of the supinators allows the forearm to pronate further, increasing the range of motion.
questions.hint: Restricted pronation and restricted posterior glide of the radial head indicate an anterior radial head dysfunction.
